entry.title: Re: custom field creation for work center maintenance pla...
entry.content:
Hi Habeeb

As I understand, the current situation is you have a created a Custom Field (type Date) for Asset Maintenance: Maintenance Order, you have also enabled it as a filter for the Manage Work Center Utilization app, which is a tile access able from the Resource Scheduling for Maintenance Planners app. Of course, because this field is empty, it returns no data - it is not associated with the Created Date for the maintenance order for example.

So at the moment you have an empty maintenance order custom field that you want to populate so you can use it for the filter.

The Manage Work Center Utilization app is not enabled for extensibility according to the Fiori App library.

However, according to the help, these are your options: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2dfa044a255f49e89a3050daf3c61c11/8014207c0ba144cc8ad58f31a6f6a8e6.html?locale=en-US

Essentially, you can adapt filters and add fields to the table with the table settings.

Unfortunately, the 2 views that you have enabled are not released (check the View Browser), so you can't work with them.

My initial idea was maybe you can create a Custom Business Object and associate the date field there with the main maintenance order. If you could do this, you can expose the CBO as a new app and edit the field there. You can check these views to see if any are suitable for this purpose (under the API tab)

However, if you could do that, introducing another app just to edit the custom field seems excessive.

You can investigate the above mentioned apis in the screenshot and check if you can do anything with Developer Extensibility or a Side by Side scenario where you update the custom field via an API.

Finally, can you use the existing Time Period field and just set it to the date of the Maintenance Order? 

If you are wanting to influence the date range of the tile in Resource Scheduling for Maintenance Planners, I unfortunately don't see a way to do that.

You may want to investigate Manage KPIs and Reports or a custom business object on one of the CDS Views in the above API screenshot to create a custom report to meet the requirement.

It would be good to revisit the original business requirement to see if there is another app or report that could be leveraged

Please let me know your thoughts

Thank you

Jerry

entry.title: Chart Enhancements in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
With the 2025 Q3 QRC release of SAP Analytics Cloud, we‚Äôre excited to introduce a series of enhancements to our Charts that are designed to provide more flexibility and control in the Optimized Experience. These updates are aimed at improving the visual appeal and the analytical precision of your dashboards, helping you tell a clearer story with your data.

Within this Blog Post, we will highlight the key enhancements which include:

  1. New Design for Numeric Point Chart
  2. Grid Lines 
  3. Axis Titles
  4. Axis Line Thickness
  5. Grouped Category Divider Line Color and Thickness

You can find an example of how these improvements can visually enhance your existing dashboard

 

New Design for Numeric Point Chart

The Numeric Point Chart has been redesigned to better align with modern dashboard aesthetics and to improve readability. With the fresh look, we ensure key figures stand out more prominently, making it easier for users to quickly grasp performance metrics.

Given that the Numeric Point Chart is significantly different, we have decided that it must be enabled on a per Chart basis which is non-reversible. For new Charts, it is automatically made available.

 

Grid Lines

We‚Äôve introduced Grid Lines which can be toggled on and off via the Designer in the Charts Show / Hide settings. It can help improve the readability of the Chart and make it easier to interpret data points that have their data labels hidden due to collision. There is an option to update the color of the Grid Lines via the Styling Panel.

 

Axis Titles

For Viewers to have better context, Designers can now add Axis Titles which reflects the name of the bound object. It helps in understanding what data is being represented on each axis.

For the Axis Title, we allow the configure of the color and position. For the X-Axis Title we support a left, center, and right alignment while for the Y-Axis we support a centre and top alignment.

 

Axis Line Thickness

The thickness of axis lines can now be adjusted between Thin, Medium, and Thick via the Styling Panel under Axis Line. It can be used to suit your design preferences or to emphasize specific aspects of a chart.

 

Grouped Category Divider Line Color and Thickness

Designers now can customize the color and thickness of divider lines between grouped dimensions. This improvement enhances the clarity of grouped data and helps in distinguishing between different segments more effectively.

 

Within the Blog Post, we also wanted to highlight a few improvements that were shipped in previous releases that could be beneficial. The key enhancements include:

  1. Adjust Bar Width at Widget Level
  2. Improved Data Label Position for "Line" based Charts
  3. Sort with 100% Stacked Bar Charts

 

Adjust Bar Width at Widget Level

You can now adjust the bar width at the widget level, instead of having to use Chart Scaling, giving designers greater control over the appearance of individual bar and column charts.

Setting the widget-level bar width overrides chart scaling bar width and default bar width settings for the chart. All other chart scaling settings are still applied.

 

Improved Data Label Position for ‚ÄúLine‚Äù based Charts

We‚Äôve improved the positioning of data labels for line-based charts to enhance readability. Labels are now placed more intelligently based on the chart layout and available space.

 

 

Sort with 100% Stacked Bar Charts

We now support sorting for 100% stacked bar charts, allowing users to order categories based on values or measures. This enhancement improves data analysis by making trends and comparisons easier to interpret.

 

These enhancements are part of our continued effort to empower users with precise, customizable, and visually engaging tools in SAP Analytics Cloud. Stay tuned for more updates as we evolve the platform to meet your analytical needs.

entry.title: How to Build Stock Validation Skills in Joule Studio
entry.content:
Build Maintenance Validation Skills Using Joule Studio  in SAP Build (Part 1)

Intro: Empowering Maintenance Operations with Joule Skills

Joule Studio enables business users and developers to build Joule Skills that automate backend tasks and simplify decision-making. In this hands-on guide ‚Äî the first of a two-part series ‚ÄîWe‚Äôll walk through creating a set of Joule Skills that help retrieve maintenance orders, fetch material and component details, and check stock availability, forming the foundation for intelligent decision-making, using a CAP-based service on SAP BTP.

We‚Äôll focus specifically on how to design, build, and test Joule Skills inside Joule Studio. The backend logic used to check maintenance order status and stock availability is already deployed as a reusable service on SAP BTP and exposed through a destination.  

Use Case: Intelligent Maintenance Stock Validation 

Maintenance planners often face delays when required components for maintenance orders are unavailable. The validation process today is manual and error prone. 

With Joule Studio, we can automate this. Our Joule Skills we‚Äôll build will: 

  • Retrieve pending maintenance orders 
  • Identify components required 
  • Check material stock availability 
  • Return the result to the user or agent consuming the skill

 

Now that we've outlined the business challenge and solution approach, let's dive into the hands-on implementation. We'll build this step-by-step, starting with the foundational setup and progressing through skill creation.

Prerequisites

Before we begin building our maintenance validation skills, you'll need access to Joule Studio. If you don't have Joule Studio set up yet, please follow the comprehensive setup guide available at: How to Get Started with Joule Studio

This guide will walk you through:

  • Accessing Joule Studio in your SAP BTP environment
  • Setting up the necessary entitlements and subscriptions
  • Configuring your development environment
  • Understanding the basic Joule Studio interface

Our Development Approach:

  1. First, we'll establish the connection to our backend service.
  2. Then, we'll create individual skills for each business function.
  3. Finally, we'll test and deploy our skills for use.

Step 1: Configure the Destination in SAP Build Lobby 

To connect Joule Studio to the backend service, you‚Äôll first configure a destination directly in the SAP Build Control Tower. 

This destination will point to an already deployed CAP service that exposes the necessary maintenance order and stock validation logic. 

Create a New Destination 

  1. Navigate to the SAP Build Lobby .
  2. Go to Control Tower > Destinations.
  3. Click ‚ÄúOpen in BTP Cockpit‚Äù.
  4. In the BTP Cockpit, Navigate to:
    • Connectivity > Destinations

 

5. Click Create Destination and fill in the following configuration: 

  • Name: sample-maintenance-service 
  • Type: HTTP 
  • Description: Maintenance Order Service
  • URL: https://sample-maintenance-srv-i760021.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com/odata/v4/maintenance-order 
  • Proxy Type: Internet 
  • Authentication: BasicAuthentication 
  • User: TECHNICAL_USER 
  • Password: TECHNICAL_PASS

 

 

 

6.  Click Check Connection to verify the destination. You should see a green checkmark if the connection is successful.

Step 2: Create an Environment in SAP Build 

Before adding destinations or creating skills in Joule Studio, you need to create an environment in SAP Build. This environment acts as the runtime space where your agents and skills will be deployed and executed. 

To create an environment: 

  1. Open the SAP Build Lobby 
  2. Navigate to Control Tower > Environments 
  3. Click Create Environment 
  4. Enter a name for your environment, e.g., Joule studio demo 
  5. (Optional) Add a description if needed 
  6. Click Create 

Later, you‚Äôll associate your destination and actions with this environment to make them usable in your skills and agents 

Step 3: Add the Destination to SAP Build  

Now that your destination is created in BTP, as we did in Step 1, we need to make it available inside SAP Build to use it in Joule Studio. 

  1. Open SAP Build Lobby 
  2. Navigate to Control Tower > Destinations 
  3. Click Add 
  4. In the wizard: Select your destination (e.g. sample-maintenance-service) 
  5. Click Next 
  6. Associate an Environment 
    1. Select the environment you created in Step 2(e.g., Joule_studio_demo) 
    2. You can choose to make the destination available in all environments or only the specific environment which you created in step 2 .
  7. Click Add Destination 

Once added, this destination will now be available to associate with environments and to use in Joule skills. 

Step 4: Add an Action in SAP Build (Expose Your API) 

Now that your destination is available and associated with an environment, the next step is to create an Action that defines how your backend API should be called by Joule skills. 

Actions are the bridge between destinations (backend APIs) and Joule Skills. 

You can upload an open API specification or build an action from scratch using the destination you added. 

Option 1: Upload OpenAPI Spec from Your Project 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Actions 
  2. Click Create > Upload API Specification 
  3. Note:The API spec is provided as a .txt file containing JSON content in the attachment.
    Before uploading, rename the file to have a .json extension  so Joule Studio correctly detects the format.
  4. Upload your openapi.json file. 
  5. Click Next to continue 
  6. You‚Äôll now be prompted to Create an Action Project. 
  7. Fill in Project Name and Description according to your use case.
    • For example, you can name the project Maintenance Fulfillment Agent API , since these APIs will later be used by a Joule Agent (covered in Part 2 of this series). 
  8. After creating the action project, you will see a list of all endpoints from your uploaded specification (you can select maximum up to 20) 
    • Select all the 6 endpoints needed for your use case. 
    • Click Add to include them in the project. 

8. Once the action is created, go to the Test tab and select the destination you created. Since the maintenance order API lists all orders, no input is required by default. If you'd like to filter by status (e.g., pending, open), you can add that later as an input parameter. Click Test to verify that the API returns a valid response. 

 

9. You should see 200: OK response from the API. 

Once tested, you can release the project to create a version of it. 

 

 10.Once released, click Publish to make the version available for Joule Skill creation 

Note: Releasing and publishing the action is required. Unpublished actions won‚Äôt appear when building a Joule Skill. 

Option 2: Alternatively: Build the Action from Scratch 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Actions 
  2. Click Create > Build from Scratch 
  3. Fill in the required fields: 
    • Operation: GET 
    • Name: Enter a name for your action (e.g., CheckMaintenanceStock) 
    • Description: Enter a brief description (e.g., Checks stock for components in a maintenance order) 
    • Endpoint: eg., /MaintenanceOrder) 
  4. Define any request parameters and expected response fields. 
  5. Click Release and Publish the action just like in the previous method for the actions to be available. 

For our use case, we will be using Option 1. 

Step 5: Create a Project and Joule Skills 

Now that the destination is configured, the environment is created, and your action has been added and published, you‚Äôre ready to build a custom Joule Skill that calls the required API from your service. 

These skills will be reusable and can later be connected to an intelligent agent in Part 2 of this series.

Create a New Skill Project 

  1. Open Joule Studio in SAP Build. 
  2. Click on create > Create Skill  
  3. Enter 
    • Project Name: eg., Intelligent Maintenance Order Stock Validation Agent‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 
    • Description: e.g., Skills to validate whether maintenance orders can be fulfilled based on stock availability
  4. Note: While we‚Äôre only creating Joule Skills in this post, we‚Äôll use the same project to add and configure the Joule Agent in Part 2 of this series.
  5. Click Review > Create 

Once the project is created, you‚Äôll be taken to the Overview tab, where you‚Äôll see the project name and description. 

 

 

The project will be created after you click ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù.  

Add a New Joule Skill 

  1. In the project, click Create 
  2. From the dropdown, select Joule Skill.
  3. Fill in: 
    • Name: e.g., GetMaintenanceOrderDetails 
    • Identifier: e.g., get-maintenance-order 
    • Description: e.g., get list of a maintenance order  
    • Click Create 

 

 

Add the Parameters to the Skill 

  1. Open the skill by clicking its name or the arrow icon to the left .This is the panel where you need to add input, output parameters.‚ÄØ 
  2. In the ‚ÄúGeneral‚Äù tab, update the name/description of the Joule skill. 
  3. Keep the toggle ‚ÄúAllow skill to be started directly by a user‚Äù ON (so the skill can be started directly by the user, not just via an agent).

     

  4. Go to the Parameters tab. Click Configure to add input and output parameters. 
  5. Inputs allow Joule to collect user input in the conversation interface. 
  6. Outputs define what information will be shown to the user after the skill executes. Add the input parameter: 

‚ûïAdd Input 

  1. Add the following Input: 
    • Name: User query 
    • Description: Context for the endpoint to give the list of the orders 
    • Required: Unchecked 
    • Click Apply to save the input. 

‚ûïAdd Output 

  1. Add the following Output: 
    • Name: List of Orders 
    • Type: Any 
    • List: Checked 
    • Required: Checked 
    • Description: List of orders depending on the user request (e.g., pending or open orders) 
  2. Click Apply to save the output. 
  3. Output types can vary ‚Äî choose the appropriate type based on the structure of your API response. 
  4. You‚Äôve now configured both input and output parameters for your Joule skill. 

Add an Action Step to the Skill 

  1. Click the ‚ûïPlus icon to add a step
    1.  
  2. Select Call Action 
  3. In the Action search: 
    • Either browse all actions 
    • Or use the search bar to quickly find your previously published action (e.g., GetMaintenanceOrderDetails) 
    • Click Add 

 

 

 

Configure the Action Step 

  1. After adding the action, you‚Äôll see General, Input, and Output tabs. 
  2. In the General tab: 
    • Set Step Name: Get maintenance orders 
    • For Destination Variable, create or select one (e.g., Fulfillment_agent) 
    • Click Create to add the destination, then select it. 
  3. Go to the Input tab and map the input (e.g., user query). 
  4. In the Output tab, you can view the API‚Äôs response schema. 
  5. Click End to configure the skill‚Äôs outputs and map the expected output value. 
  6. Click Save to finish the step configuration. 

 

 

Create Skills for Each API Endpoint 

We have already created a skill which uses GET/MaintenanceOrder‚ÄØ 

 

Tool Name 

Endpoint 

Description 

GetMaintenanceOrders 

GET /MaintenanceOrder 

Retrieve all maintenance orders (can be filtered) 

GetMaintenanceOrderDetails 

GET /MaintenanceOrder('{ID}') 

Get details of a specific maintenance order 

cGetOrderOperations 

GET /MaintenanceOrder('{ID}')/operation 

List operations under a maintenance order 

GetOperationComponents 

GET /Operation('{ID}')/component 

List components for a specific operation 

GetMaterialDetails 

GET /Material('{ID}') 

Get material details 

GetMaterialStockLevels 

GET /Material('{ID}')/stockLevel 

Check stock availability for a material 

 

For each skill, remember to: 

  • Configure input and output parameters.
  • Set the correct destination variable.
  • Turn on ‚ÄúAllow skill to be started directly by a user‚Äù if creating Joule Skills.

Tip: Use the Action Definition to Configure Skill Parameters 

When configuring the Skill Input and Skill Output, you don‚Äôt need to guess what the API expects or returns. 

You can find this information directly from the Action definition you uploaded earlier: 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Actions.
  2. Open the Action project you created .
  3. Select the relevant endpoint.
  4. Navigate to the Input and Output tabs 

From there, you can: 

  • See which input parameters are required 
  • Understand the expected output structure and data types 

 

 

 

 

Example: For GET /Operation('{ID}')/component 

  • Input: ID of the operation (marked with a red asterisk = required) .
  • Output: 
    • value ‚Üí A list of components (type: list) 
    • count ‚Üí Number of items (type: number) 

Use this information to accurately define the parameters in your Joule Skill > Parameters tab. 

  

Step 6: Release and Deploy Joule Skills 

With your Joule Skills created and configured, the next step is to release and deploy them to your environment so they can be used in real scenarios.

  1. Click Release to version your Project.

  

       2. Go to Project > Versions 

       3. Click Deploy 

 

 

During deployment: 

  1. Select the Environment created in Step 2 (e.g., Joule Studio demo) 
  2. Select the Destination you added in Step 3 
    • You will only see destinations that are: 
      • Associated with this environment 
      • Or made available to All Environments 
  3. Click Deploy 
  4. After deployment, the agent status will appear as Active 

 

 

 

Test the Skills in Joule Studio

To interact with your the skills: 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Environments 
  2. Click your environment (e.g., joule studio demo) 
  3. Under your agent project, click More > Joule 
  4. Click Launch to open the Joule Chat window 

You can now start chatting with your agent using real-world prompts. 

 

For example: 


Debugging Agents Flow 

  • You can open the Debug Panel in the top right corner to see details of how Joule selects the skills based on the user input.‚ÄØ 

Example Prompts to Test the Joule skills

  1. ‚ÄúShow me all current maintenance orders‚Äù 
  2. ‚ÄúGet details for maintenance order 25‚Äù 
  3. ‚ÄúWhat operations are planned for maintenance order 4?‚Äù 
  4. ‚ÄúWhat is the description of material 19‚Äù 
  5. ‚ÄúHow many units of material M-45678 are in stock?‚Äù 

Wrapping Up Part 1: Skills First, Intelligence Next

In this first part of our Joule Studio blog series, we focused on building the foundation: creating, configuring, and deploying individual Joule Skills that interact with maintenance orders and material data. These skills are now live, testable, and ready to be reused across various automation and intelligence layers.

Each skill is designed to handle a focused task ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs fetching order details, retrieving stock levels, or listing required components. With these deployed, you're now ready to take the next leap: combining them into an intelligent agent.

In Part 2, we‚Äôll build a Joule Agent that brings your deployed skills together into an intelligent assistant ‚Äî one that can understand maintenance-related questions, check if orders can be fulfilled, identify what‚Äôs blocking them, and even suggest solutions such as replenishment needs or follow-up actions.


Part 2 will show you how to build an intelligent maintenance agent that brings your skills to life ‚Äî stay tuned!

If you're interested in diving deeper into Joule Studio and expanding your knowledge beyond this use case, here are valuable resources to accelerate your learning:

Learning Resources

  • Learning Journey - Comprehensive guided learning path for Joule Studio
  • Documentation - Official technical documentation and reference guides
  • Discovery Center Mission - Hands-on missions to build practical skills
  • Joule Studio Tutorials - Step-by-step development tutorials
  • Architecture Overview - Technical architecture and integration patterns
  • Smart Advisory Companion ‚Äì Inspiration Video - See Joule Studio in action with real-world scenarios

These resources will help you explore additional use cases, advanced features, and best practices for building intelligent automation solutions with Joule Studio.

entry.title: Sustainability Control Tower: Update on SAP-provided Metrics on ESRS regulation (continued)
entry.content:
This is a continuation of Sustainability Control Tower: Update on SAP-provid... - SAP Community

Co-author @elsandoval 

Disclaimer: This blog post reflects the state of the SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) as of July 25th,  2025. 

SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) supports customers on ESG reporting. Therefore, SCT enhances the coverage of metrics provided which are in line with the European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS). 

This blog-post provides an overview of metrics which are planned or newly released and gets updated regularly. Please note that the names of planned metrics may be subject to change. For the full list of available metrics in SCT, please visit Metrics | SAP Help Portal 

Released Metrics (as of July 25th 2025)
In some cases metrics are marked as "(documentation only)". That means those datapoints are not part of the scope of standard metrics delivered by SAP and therefore documentation is provided in the help portal. This is the case if e.g. for quantitative metrics a customer specific breakdown is requested or for qualitative metrics, in case datapoints are already covered in other datapoints. 

Qualitative

Sustainability MatterMetric NameDisclosure RequirementData Point
WORKERS IN THE VALUE CHAINAre All Value Chain Workers in Scope of Material IROs S2.SBM-3(11)(AR 6-AR 7)
WORKERS IN THE VALUE CHAINTypes of Value Chain Workers Subject to Material ImpactsS2.SBM-3(11a)
WORKERS IN THE VALUE CHAIN(Documentation only)
Type of value chain workers subject to material impacts by own operations or through value chain
S2.SBM-3(11ai-v)
WORKERS IN THE VALUE CHAINGeographic Area/Commodity with Risk of Child/Forced Labor in Value Chain WorkersS2.SBM-3(11b)
WORKERS IN THE VALUE CHAINNature of Material Negative Impacts on Value Chain WorkersS2.SBM-3(11c)
WORKERS IN THE VALUE CHAINPositive Impacts on Workers: Activities, Affected Employee Type, and GeographiesS2.SBM-3(11d)
WORKERS IN THE VALUE CHAINMaterial Risks and Opportunities Related to Value Chain WorkersS2.SBM-3(11e)
WORKERS IN THE VALUE CHAINAssessment of Value Chain Workers at Greater Risk of HarmS2.SBM-3(12)(AR 8 )
WORKERS IN THE VALUE CHAINMaterial Risks and Opportunities Related to Specific Value Chain Worker GroupsS2.SBM-3(13)(AR 9)
WORKERS IN THE VALUE CHAINHuman Rights Policy Commitments Relevant to Value Chain WorkersS2-1(17)
WORKERS IN THE VALUE CHAINGeneral Approach to Human and Labor Rights for Value Chain WorkersS2-1(17a)

entry.title: Re: SAP Business Data Cloud - FAQs
entry.content:
@SreekanthSurampally 

Customers can also create their  own data products using data from any SAP or non-SAP application. These are called customer-managed data products and are created and managed in SAP Datasphere.

The data and its related ORD file are stored in the customer‚Äôs storage area within SAP Datasphere (Embedded Object Store). Both customer-managed and standard data products work the same way ‚Äî they are stored in an object store, described by an ORD file, and published in the SAP BDC Catalog.

entry.title: Re: Local RAP business event consumption in S/4HANA 2023 OP
entry.content:
If the events are not in a released API, then you can make a request to SAP via Customer Influence platform for new feature and hope that they put this on their roadmap.

Following page explains that business event can be consumed locally: Business Event Consumption | SAP Help Portal
I pasted the steps from there.

Creating an Event Handler Class

1. Create a class that will serve as the event handler class. For the introductory syntax of the global class, use the keyword FOR EVENTS OF, followed by the name of the behavior definition that contains the event to be consumed.

 
CLASS cl_local_event_consumption DEFINITION
						PUBLIC
						ABSTRACT
						FINAL
						FOR EVENTS OF root_entity.
 

2. In the definition section of the local class contained in the Local Types, include cl_abap_behavior_event_handler as superclass to inherit from.

 
CLASS lcl_local_event_consumption DEFINITION INHERITING FROM cl_abap_behavior_event_handler.
 

3. Define a method for each event to be handled. In the method signature, specify the importing parameter, the entity, as well as the event to be consumed.

 
PRIVATE SECTION.
              METHODS consume_event_1 FOR ENTITY EVENT importing_parameter_1 FOR my_entity~event_1.
              METHODS consume_event_2 FOR ENTITY EVENT importing_parameter_2 FOR my_entity~event_2.
            ...ENDCLASS.

            CLASS lcl_local_event_consumption IMPLEMENTATION.
            METHOD consume_event_1.
              CHECK importing_parameter_1 IS NOT INITIAL.
            ... ENDMETHOD.

            METHOD consume_event_2.
              CHECK importing_parameter_2 IS NOT INITIAL.
            ... ENDMETHOD.
            ENDCLASS.

entry.title: Enhancing Your SAP Support Experience ‚Äì Sunset of Ask an Expert Peer
entry.content:
Your support experience matter! ‚Äì and we are evolving with purpose to meet your changing needs and provide you with the best support experience. As technology advances and business demands grow, we continuously refine our support strategy to deliver faster, smarter, and more personalized assistance. As of July 1, 2025, we simplified our support channels by retiring the Real-Time Support live channel ‚ÄúAsk an Expert Peer‚Äù in SAP for Me. This change is the beginning of a more agile and connected support experience.

What Changed?

To better align with your needs, we‚Äôve officially retired the Ask an Expert Peer option in SAP for Me. You may notice that the familiar button has been removed from the ‚ÄòBest Action‚Äô recommender in the ‚ÄòGet Support‚Äô application.

Why the Change?

By sharpening our focus on proven support live channels, we‚Äôre enhancing your ability to get answers when you need them. SAP is committed to delivering a consistent, intelligent, and outcome-driven support experience. After careful evaluation and customer feedback, we are consolidating our efforts into scalable and intelligent Real-Time Support channels that offer broader coverage and tighter integration into SAP's support and product ecosystem.

  • Faster Resolutions: By focusing on the most effective channels, you‚Äôll get answers and solutions quicker than ever.
  • Consistent Expertise: Enhanced live channels provides you access to the best expertise.

We encourage you to take full advantage of SAP‚Äôs Real-Time Support portfolio, designed to give you faster answers, expert guidance, and AI-powered insights when and where you need them.

What Does It Mean for You?

  • In SAP for Me, you‚Äôll now be seamlessly guided to our highest-performing live support channels like Case, Expert Chat, Schedule a Manager and Schedule an Expert.
  • If you previously relied on Ask an Expert Peer, transitioning to these optimized channels will feel intuitive and efficient.

üí°Good to know: Want to keep content from your previous Ask an Expert Peer sessions? You can export your history via the ‚ÄòCase List‚Äô application.

Note:
Ask an Expert Peer will continue to be available in the Ariba Help Center. You can find more information in this SAP Knowledge Base article: 2998816 - Ask an Expert Peer - Frequently Asked Questions - SAP Technical Support

Your SAP Support Team

entry.title: Re: SAP Datasphere catalog - Harvesting from SAP BW/4HANA
entry.content:
Hi @PuneetMishra Based on the information provided, I would start by verifying the SAP Cloud Connector setup

  1. Confirm that the Cloud to On-Premise system mapping has been completed and is correctly configured in the SAP Cloud Connector.
  2. Ensure that the BW/4HANA resources are properly defined in the SAP Cloud Connector.
  3. Verify that the system is up to date and that the relevant services are enabled, as described in SAP Note 3601550.

Next, test the BW/4HANA endpoints in your preferred browser to ensure they are accessible.
For example:

  • https://<bw4hana-host>/sap/bw/ina/GetServerInfo
  • https://<bw4hana-host>/sap/bc/http/sap/bw4/v1/system/information

Regards,
Babu

entry.title: Re: Consume an Event using Event Consumption Model
entry.content:
Hello @SafaBahoosh ,
Standard event doesn't have the information that is needed by the event consumer, so our requirement is to trigger a custom event whenever a standard event is triggered. I tried event extension(using Derived Events concept explained in the blog below), but event extension is possible only with S4 2023(ABAP 7.58 or later) and we are still on S4 2022(ABAP 7.57).
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/derived-events-how-to-trigger-custom-event-from-an-sap-standard-event/ba-p/13955193

I then tried to consume events locally using a local event handler(similar to example mentioned in below blog). However, CLASS FOR EVENTS keyword used to consume events locally is again available only with S4 2023.
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/working-with-rap-bo-events-end-to-end-event-driven-architecture-event/ba-p/14018775

Another option is to create an event consumption model, to consume an event from Event mesh. But this doesn't look like an efficient way, since we are trying to consume an event from event mesh that was  originally triggered locally.

What are the options to send a custom payload (whenever a standard event is trigged) on S4 OP 2022 (other than the legacy ways)?

entry.title: Re: Derived Events- How to Trigger Custom Event from an SAP Standard Event
entry.content:
Hello @SafaBahoosh ,
Standard event doesn't have the information that is needed by the event consumer, so our requirement is to trigger a custom event whenever a standard event is triggered. I tried event extension(using example shown in this blog ), but event extension is possible only with S4 2023(ABAP 7.58 or later) and we are still on S4 2022(ABAP 7.57).

I then tried to consume events locally using a local event handler(similar to example mentioned in below blog). However, CLASS FOR EVENTS keyword used to consume events locally is again available only with S4 2023.
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/working-with-rap-bo-events-end-to-end-even...

Another option is to create an event consumption model, to consume an event from Event mesh. But this doesn't look like an efficient way, since we are trying to consume an event from event mesh that was  originally triggered locally.

What are the options to send a custom payload (whenever a standard event is trigged) on S4 OP 2022 (other than the legacy ways)?

entry.title: Succession Org Chart Reporting
entry.content:
Hello! We are using position-based SOC (succession org chart) WITHOUT position management. We are trying to see if there is a way to capture periodic reporting snapshots of the SOC if vacant positions drop off due to the intricacies that happen with our org chart sync process.

Has anyone found the ability to take snapshots of the SOC through Report Center? The fields there seem limited, Specifically, we want to capture through a report vacant positions and their successors before they inadvertently drop off the SOC due to timing issues and other things unique to the sync process.

A periodic reporting snapshot would help this, but there doesn't seem to be the full field set to do so. Any ideas? Again, the root problem we are trying to solve for is when vacant position tiles drop off, and we need to restore them manually. Need a report to tell us what specific information to restore for that tile that dropped off.

We are also in the midst of troubleshooting our succession org chart sync process. Is there a call anytime with this group to exchange experiences and learn best practices that other customers have had troubleshooting their SOC data and keeping it clean?

entry.title: Queue Browser: Deep Message Visibility for Event Mesh in SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Introduction

In event-driven architectures, messages flow continuously between systems, carrying critical business data and triggering essential processes. When something goes wrong‚Äîmessages pile up, integrations fail, or data appears corrupted‚Äîyou need immediate visibility into what‚Äôs happening inside your queues. Without this insight, troubleshooting becomes a frustrating game of guesswork.

Monitoring message queues is essential in event‚Äëdriven architectures. It reveals queue health and uncovers bottlenecks, providing crucial delivery and routing insights that ensure system reliability. With the latest release of Event Mesh in SAP Integration Suite, we‚Äôre excited to announce Queue Browser, a new capability that delivers deep message visibility through an intuitive web‚Äëbased interface.

The key advantage: Visualizing and inspecting messages using Queue Browser won't consume them from the message broker queue, so you can safely examine message metadata‚Äîsuch as headers, statuses, and errors‚Äîand troubleshoot malformed payloads without disrupting live processing.

What is Queue Browser in Event Mesh in SAP Integration Suite?

Queue Browser is a web-based monitoring and diagnostics tool that allows you to inspect messages in a queue without consuming them from the message broker queue. Think of it as a "read-only window" into your message queues‚Äîyou can see everything that's happening without affecting the actual message flow.

Queue Browser bridges the gap between high-level queue metrics and detailed application logs, giving you the message-level insight needed for effective troubleshooting.

Key Capabilities

  • Search & Filter: Quickly locate messages by criteria such as message ID, correlation ID, and custom properties.
  • Header, Payload, and Custom Properties Inspection: View standard JMS-style headers (timestamp, delivery mode, Dead Message Queue eligibility) and examine the message payload alongside any custom properties. This is invaluable for validating data transformations and ensuring message integrity.
  • Message Management: Identify and inspect stuck or problematic messages in queues, with the option to delete them when needed.
  • Purge Queues: Clear all messages from a selected queue in one action, ideal for resetting test environments or clearing backed-up queues during maintenance.

Queue Browser in action

Accessing the Queue Browser

Step 1: Navigate to Queue Monitoring

In the SAP Integration Suite Cockpit, open the left‚Äëhand menu and navigate to:

Monitor ‚Ä∫ Event Mesh ‚Ä∫ Queues

Step 2: Review Queue Metrics

You‚Äôll see a comprehensive table listing all your queues with real-time usage metrics:

Monitoring Event Mesh Usage ‚Äì Queue List Floorplan

  • Name: The name of the queue
  • Messages Queued: Number of messages in the queue
  • Unacknowledged Messages: Number of unacknowledged messages in the queue. Messages delivered but not yet acknowledged as processed.
  • Queue Size: The queue size in bytes.
  • Max Queue Size: The maximum size possible for the queue in bytes.

These metrics provide immediate insight into queue health‚Äîhigh unacknowledged message counts often indicate processing issues, while queues approaching their size limits may need attention.

Step 3: Drill Down to Message List

Message List Report Floorplan

Select any queue to drill down to its message list page, where you can view some per‚Äëmessage information:

  • Message ID: Identifier for tracking messages
  • Correlation ID: Identifier to trace the request journey
  • Time Sent: Time the message was sent
  • Message Size: The size of the message content, in bytes
  • Redelivered: Indicates if the message was redelivered or not‚Äîa key troubleshooting indicator
  • Destination: Destination of the message
  • DMQ Eligible: Indicates whether the message is eligible for the Dead Message Queue (DMQ)

Step 4: Inspect Individual Messages

Message Details ‚Äì Object Page Floorplan

Click a message entry to navigate to its details page. The level of access depends on your assigned roles:

Users can review the message headers by default; if your BTP user has the EventMeshBusinessExpert role collection assigned, you‚Äôll also see the full payload and any custom properties.

Security Note: Access to single‚Äëmessage inspection is restricted to specific roles only. Only users assigned the EventMeshBusinessExpert role collection should be granted permission to view full message payloads and custom properties and delete messages. This ensures that message access is tightly controlled per organizational requirements and can be managed via Configuring User Access.

Message Detail Components

Headers Information

  • Identifiers
    • Message ID: Identifier for tracking messages
    • Correlation ID: Identifier to trace the request journey
  • Delivery Information
    • Time Sent: Time the message was sent
    • Redelivered: Indicates if the message was redelivered or not‚Äîa key troubleshooting indicator
    • Delivery Mode: The mode which is used for message delivery
  • Routing Information
    • Destination: The destination of the message
    • Reply To: The address or topic to which the recipient should send the response, when a message that requires a reply or acknowledgment, is published.
    • DMQ Eligible: Indicates whether the message is eligible for the Dead Message Queue (DMQ)
  • Additional Information: Message size in bytes

Payload

The message payload contains the actual business data being transmitted between systems.

Custom Properties

Custom properties contain business-specific metadata that applications attach to messages. These might include:

  • Customer IDs for filtering
  • Source system identifiers for tracing

This metadata is invaluable for understanding message context and implementing sophisticated filtering strategies.

Available Actions

From the message detail page, users with appropriate permissions can:

  • Delete individual problematic messages
  • Download message payloads for offline analysis
  • Copy message IDs and correlation IDs for use in other tools

Conclusion

The Queue Browser for Event Mesh in SAP Integration Suite transforms how you monitor and troubleshoot event-driven systems. By providing safe, non-disruptive message inspection, it empowers you to validate message content before processing, diagnose complex integration issues, and ensure smooth data flow.

Next Steps

  1. Explore Queue Browser in your SAP Integration Suite tenant‚Äînavigate to Monitor ‚Ä∫ Event Mesh ‚Ä∫ Queues
  2. Review the official documentation:
    • Monitor Event Mesh
    • Configuring User Access
    • Personas & Permissions
  3. Share your experience on the SAP Community‚Äîhelp others understand how Queue Browser improves their troubleshooting workflows

Queue Browser puts the visibility and control you need right at your fingertips. Start exploring your message queues today and experience the difference that comprehensive message visualization and inspection makes in maintaining event-driven architectures.

Happy monitoring!
